meanings.def: a thick piece of wood that is cut from or has fallen from a tree
examples: logs for the fire
The road was blocked by fallen logs.
They haul the logs into the sawmill.
a pile of sawn logs
logs crackling in the fireplace

meanings.def: an official record of events during a particular period of time, especially a journey on a ship or plane
examples: The captain keeps a log.
They keep a log of any accidents that occur at work.
She kept a log of their voyage.
A senior officer made a note in the ship's log.
The captain's log stopped abruptly in May 1944.

meanings.def: a written or digital record of activity on a computer or phone line
examples: I checked the server's error logs.
The lawyers will review phone logs and other records.

meanings.def: a logarithm (= any of a series of numbers set out in lists that make it possible to work out problems by adding and subtracting instead of multiplying and dividing)

examples: The whole procedure is as easy as ABC.
Fooling him was as easy as falling off a log.
He was so tired after all his exertions, he slept like a baby.
I usually sleep like a log.

idioms.idiom: as easy as anything/as pie/as ABC/as falling off a log
examples: The whole procedure is as easy as ABC.
Fooling him was as easy as falling off a log.
He was so tired after all his exertions, he slept like a baby.
I usually sleep like a log.
a dialog

meanings.def: to put information in an official record or write a record of events
examples: The police log all phone calls.
It was a diary logging life on a sailing ship in the 1870s.
The call was logged at 16.20.
The crimes were logged but not investigated.

meanings.def: to travel a particular distance or for a particular length of time
examples: The pilot has logged 1 000 hours in the air.

meanings.def: to cut down trees in a forest for their wood
